title: Will a framework for an end to the Syrian conflict be agreed upon by 31 December 2017?
preds: The stability is still uncertain and based on Russia's moves, as well as shia militia, it would create certainty where uncertainty would exist.
TRUMP IS NOT INTERESTED IN ROCKING THE RUSSIAN SPHERE OF INFLUENCE IN THE MIDDLE EAST AS A GIVE AWAY.
Not a critical mass of participants
Timeline is closing in a few hours.
It's the 31st and it hasn't happened yet (and I doubt that will happen any time soon...)
Suspect this may come after result of attempts to destabilize Iranian government.

There will not be an announcement of that type prior to an event prompted/attempt to either 1) defame/embarrass the coalition (hero) Forces (Inherent Resolve)  2) Claim success in megalomaniacal fashion for Coalition Successes. Both are likely underpinned by the handful of vile ISIS cowards who find, at minimum, safe passage/blind eyed state in lands controlled by the regime (Russia). These bad-actors are likely a card to be played in the aforementioned post-coalition announcement of successes directly against the Coalition, or, more likely, on the Iraqi State Forces etc.. who have been instrumental in the 98% reclaiming of ISIS held territory by Coalition forces, and liberation of 7.7 million people.
Russia is in the middle of a military buildup in the region. There is a higher chance that tensions will escalate into 2018.
We wish they could end their dispute yet.......

This a Chess game. Russia is looking to rile the West, specifically the US, and Erdogan is looking for international brownie points to distract from his anti-democratic actions at home. They will wait for international reaction before any real moves are made.
Assad and Putin will wait at least until Spring.
There wont  be  a solution  in Syria  unless Russia wants  there  to  be.

The Syrian regime has no desire to relinquish power and they have a powerful ally in Russia, one of the co-sponsors of the conference. There will be talks but they will not lead to a significant change in the power structure of Syria. A new constitution and U.N.-supervised elections would be too risky for the Syrian president, so he and his regime will resist such a framework. Russia will do little to force the issue and may even undermine their own stated efforts.

It's possible that such an announcement could be made, but the month is almost over and I don't see why the countries involved would have any special stake in finishing the agreement before the end of 2017. There is also the current shuffling of Arab opinions about Israel and the US, especially where Egypt, Jordan and Turkey are concerned. Israel doesn't want Iranian bases near the southern border of Syria, while Jordan has been playing both sides of the fence and Turkey wants to Iran and Syria to help control the Kurds, but isn't in favor of Al Asad. There are probably still quite a few things to work out before an agreement is announced, and no reason to rush it.

The entire process seems to have stalled a bit. The situation does not currently command the attention it once did. It seems to have served a very specific purpose in the media circles, and its usefulness (making the world "aware") has since passed.

Syria's only motive is to root out ISIS and its collaborators and prevent the Kurds from breaking up the country. Assad has never been more popular. For what would he do that? If he did, it would only lengthen the real conflict.

Dictators who flagrantly abuse human rights, do so to demonstrate that they are unaccountable for their actions so long as they are in power. Assad should never willingly surrender power under any peaceful terms.
Time frame is to short for a political settlement.

Loose framework perhaps. The region is far from stable, with too many different nations pushing their own agenda. Syria will remain militarized and occupied for years to come. Perhaps resulting in something similar to East and West Berlin, or Israel and Palestine
There is no reason for Syria to want a new Constitution nor a reason for Russia to cooperate with the U.N..
Seeing that we're now six days away from this deadline and the framework is not in the news yet, unlikely.
You have participant involved who will carry on the fight for years
Current news of peace negotiations is hard to find. Going off of http://www.novinite.com/articles/186524/Deutsche+Welle%3A+Syria+Astana+Talks+End+with+Call+For+New+Peace+Round+in+Sochi
There seems to be a very low likelihood of a deal:
May have already been agreed in secret.
This ceasefire will have to last MUCH longer before an agreement is reached.
Too short of time to finish the discussions, more likely to be completed by March or April.
Al-Assad will not agree to a new constitution and elections within this time frame.
No chance. It would mean the end of the Assad regime.
That is 10 days away, too short a time for a major agreement to move from proposed conference to ratificationâ€‹.
Assad must die first for this question to resolve as a "yes."

That's a pretty specific set of criteria that need to be met for a "yes":
a) credible media source announcing a framework, AND
b) plan to adopt a new constitution, AND
c) agreement that an election will be held, AND
d) that election will involve UN supervision.

There are over 30 opposition groups in the country, the majority of which have to come to an agreement to move forward with Assad still in power, and they have to lay down their arms. ISIL is a confounding factor and these groups may still need to be armed to prevent ISIL penetration into their areas. The US still has a military role in protecting the Syrian people's interests as well as fighting ISIL. The US has to agree to some future role. The last meeting was in December, so It's very unlikely that Putin will be able to put this together before year end... or even in the first 3 to 6 months of 2018.
No indication of agreed framework in the works or being built
No new updates indicates this is a very low probability event.
The US and Russia will co-operate more in seeking a solution now that the Russians have withdrawn most of their military support. I see a solution in the intermediate term but not the short term.

Complexity of framework (new constitution and monitored elections) is likely uninteresting to Assad due to his recent military consolidations, and even if it was the timeframe for agreeing such detailed efforts is lengthy, so not realistic to finalize before 31 Dec 2017.

I don't believe the pressure being brought to bear against Assad is sufficient for him to agree to surrender power, which are at least psychological and political prerequisites for a new constitution and elections.
A casual look at the map shows who has won the Syrian Civil war, Assad and also the Kurds.
things seem less stable in middle east
These things never (well, hardly ever) move this quickly.
Assad will not agree to elections.
Definitely not going to happen this month.

Russia and Iran is very unlikely to get by-in from Western nations as they still have reservations over Assad's rule. His military has undoubtedly committed war crimes and cannot be trusted to lead his country with out further violence and repression. He has also failed to eliminate his full chemical weapons program which will lend only mistrust and hesitation by the west to support any future involving his rule.

The problem with this and many of the more recent questions is the extremely tight time frame given. This might be an interesting question if the terminal date was 31 December 2018, but given that it closes at the end of this month it's simply ridiculous.
Not even a month left and the scenario sounds like a huge and specific breakthrough.

The situation today
Syrian troops entered Deir Az Zor from the east on September 18, increasing chances of a standoff with US-backed SDF forces operating nearby. Earlier in September, there had been an ISIL evacuation from Lebanon to Deir Az Zor.

1.  Saleh's death really impacts this.  
2. Today, we shall learn whether the Syrian government's delegation will return to Geneva for talks scheduled to run through 15 Dec.  
3.  Take a look at 
http://www.nydailynews.com/newswires/news/world/latest-syria-opposition-transition-assad-article-1.3678285, which drives home the fact that two contingents have diametrically opposed views, and are not yet ready to consider options inbetween the extremes: a) new government must not include President Assad, b) the new governent must include him.
4.  The logistics involved with holding an election is huge. The influencing factors include all of the facets of a war-torn region.  An example: an election is only fair if all eligible voters have the opportunity to submit a choice.  When the transportation infrastructure is damaged, this is hard to guarantee. To pull that off by the end of 2017, I find unlikely.
Time frame too short, conditions to exact, and participants newly belligerent.  Plus, Saleh's death means Yemen will now occupy the front burner in peacemakers' minds.

There is no agreed upon conference date yet, let alone a framework for an end to the conflict.  I could see a framework as more likely if it didn't include the two caveats of a new constitution and UN elections.

Marwan Kabalan, an analyst with the Doha Institute, noted that the fate of Assad would long remain a contentious issue: "A significant part of the country in the north and south, holding most of the oil and water reserves, is not under the control of the regime. This means the conflict will last much, much longer than people expect."
http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/11/expect-syria-talks-171127093905806.html

This outcome could be possible if Russia takes the unorthodox lead in executing the UN mandate and effectively masquerading as an impartial actor. By negotiating an overall end to the conflict and insulating the Assad government but not actually committing to anything, a "peaceful" settlement could be reached.
The interests of these countries are not conjunction with the majority of the Syrian people.

UN negotiations in Geneva can not even get the parties in same room. This: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-talks/syrian-government-negotiator-quits-geneva-talks-says-may-not-return-idUSKBN1DV4U8

The various players in the conflict - chiefly the Assad govt, will not have all that they want lined up within that timeframe.  Russia is unconcerned w/longer conflict.  Iran somewhat of a wildcard, as US (and Gulf state) pressure could give reason to use participation in Syrian conflict as leverage.
The web of actors involved is too complex to achieve this within 1  month
No way is Assad agreeing to a U.N. supervised election.
Assad is back, and he sent a team to Geneva.
